newsitem.title: USA: Borg-Warner Automotive seeks buyer for unit.
newsitem.headline: Borg-Warner Automotive seeks buyer for unit.

text.p: Borg-Warner Automotive Inc said Wednesday it planned to seek a buyer for its forged powdered metal engine connecting rod business unit, citing a lack of strategic fit with its core businesses.
Borg-Warner said it has retained Lehman Brothers to solicit proposals from qualified purchasers. The company said it will only sell the business if an acceptable buyer is found.
The connecting rod product line was acquired as part of the company's 1995 purchase of the Precision Forged Products Division from Federal-Mogul Corp.
The connecting rod product line represented less than 15 percent of the division's total revenue at the time but is expected to grow to almost $35 million in 1997, Borg-Warner said.

"While the connecting rod business is experiencing rapid growth and is a solid, process-oriented business, it does not offer a strategic fit with our core businesses," John Fiedler, Borg-Warner Automotive chairman and chief executive, said in a statement.
Borg-Warner said the company knew the line was not a good fit but continued to invest in it to assure continued service and to take full advantage of the growth opportunities.
"Our resources are better spent, however, on the core technologies that will drive our growth and profitability in highly-engineered products and systems," Fiedler said.
The connecting rod business is located in Romulus, Michigan, and employs 330 people.
Borg-Warner supplies engineered components and systems, primarily for automotive drivetrain applications.
